courses.subject: BEHM
courses.title: Zero to IPO: Introduction to Biomedical Enterprises
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the full life cycle of biomedical enterprises, from research idea to Initial Public Offering (IPO). Covering broad topics such as company incorporation, financial assessment, licensing, regulatory requirements, and development strategy, students will complete the course well-equipped with the core concepts necessary to work in biomedical business development, management, and venture capital roles.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

* Understand the fundamentals of the legal and financial terms and procedures associated with company incorporation.
* Understand the valuation life cycle of companies starting from university licensing, all the way to acquisition / IPO / merger and beyond.
* Evaluate financial metrics and valuation methods used in the biomedical industry.
* Understand the FDA and NMPA regulatory approval processes.
* Identify and triage key risk factors associated with biomedical development, including regulatory, scientific, development, and execution risks.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to the Life Cycle of Biomedical Companies

* Understanding the difference between R&D-focused pre-revenue and revenue-positive biomedical companies; their fundamental valuation and philosophical differences.
* Understanding overall life cycle for both:
+ - R&D: Therapeutic FDA+NMPA Phase IND 1, 2, 3, 4 process. Basic IPO / acquisition requirements. Parallels in medical devices.
- Revenue: growth, traction, dividend share, basic IPO requirements.
* Historical context of biotech IPOs – what made Boston successful.

Week 2: Before Starting a Company

* Understanding scientific, market, and regulatory dynamics and trends.
* Competitor analysis and market comparable calculations.
* Identifying clinical needs, matching clinical standard of care and workflow.
* Seeking product-market fit and understanding reimbursement models.
* Overview of regulatory bodies
* The three P’s: Patents, Project, People (critical considerations in company formation).

Week 3: Starting a Company

* Assessing typical corporate setup models, especially unique structures for investment consideration in Hong Kong and China.
* Going through a Term Sheet in detail, understanding all terminology and core principles: pre/post-money valuation, dilution, ROFR, ESOP, vesting, etc.).
* Financial modeling and developing a business plan.

Week 4: Deal Considerations

* Financial statements and reporting for biotech companies.
* Understanding funding sources and capital structure.
* Financial modeling and valuation techniques.
* Building and assessing typical transaction documents: Non-Disclosure Agreements, Shareholders Agreement, Share Purchase Agreement, Articles of Association, Cap Table, Employee Stock Option Pool, and common side letters (Anti-Dilution, Rights of First Refusal).

Week 5: Raising Venture Capital… or not?

* Overview of the different types of investors by stage: early stage (angels, F&F, accelerators) vs Venture Capital vs Private Equity vs Pre-IPO vs Secondary vs Hedge Funds.
* Overview of different types of investors by risk appetite: family office, endowments, insurance companies, CVC.
* Historical return of funds, and investor expectations accordingly.
* The importance of timing and storytelling.

Week 6: Exit Strategy

* Developing an exit strategy for the company: M&A, licensing, IPO, maintain privatization with dividends and share buybacks.
* Which path to choose, when, and why.
* Understanding Big Pharma – collaboration, licensing, and exit channel.
* Managing investor relations and communications.
* Preparing for roadshows and presentations.
* Steps involved in launching an IPO.
* Pricing and allocation of shares.
* Common pitfalls during the IPO process.
* Market volatility, speculation, post-IPO performance and stabilization.

Week 7: Ethics

* Difference between Ethics, Etiquette, and Civics in the free market.
* Tools for evaluation: Rawlsian Veil of Ignorance, Kierkegaardian Categorical Imperative.
* Utilitarianism and Deontology.

Week 8-9: Case Studies and Class discussions/ Students’ assessment

* In-depth analysis of notable Hong Kong biotech deals
* Lessons learned from successes and failures.

* Guest speakers: industry experts and IPO veterans.

Week 10: Company visit

Week 11: Future Trends in Biotech IPOs

* Emerging trends and technologies in the biotech space.
* The impact of global markets on biotech IPOs.
* Predictions for the future landscape of biotech financing.
* Dealflow channels for capturing leading science.

Week 12-13: Mock Investment Committee Day (Project Presentation)

* Taking everything learned, students will do a real-time dive and analysis of a legacy company data room. The class would be split into teams to study a specific area of a deal, and be given 20 minutes to do a quick write up and conclusion. Each team then presents their part i.e. scientific analysis team, financing team, legal team, market comparables team, all share their findings, and at the end of the class, the class will come together for a moderated discussion to vote on whether or not, and how much to invest in said mock biotech deal.

courses.subject: BEHM
courses.title: Internship
courses.description: The BEHM4000 Summer Internship Program is designed to provide Year 3 or above BEHM students with practical hands-on experience in the field of Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management. Through this internship, students will have the opportunity to integrate their knowledge and skills acquired in previous courses into real-world settings. They will develop problem-solving abilities, enhance teamwork skills, and gain valuable industry experience to support their career development.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the internship program, students are expected to:

1. Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical skills acquired in previous courses into real-world scenarios.
2. Design, organize, schedule, and execute individual or group projects related to Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management.
3. Acquire hands-on techniques in conducting experiments or special projects provided by the internship provider.
4. Develop effective problem-solving abilities in the context of the biotechnology, entrepreneurship, and healthcare management sectors.
5. Work collaboratively with a team in a professional laboratory or company setting.
6. Cultivate a sense of responsibility and professionalism in the workplace.
7. Gain empirical experiences and out-of-classroom experiences to support career development in the field of Biotechnology, Entrepreneurship, and Healthcare Management.
8. Improve written communication skills through the preparation of comprehensive internship reports.

courses.subject: BEHM
courses.title: Capstone Project I
courses.description: This course is part I of the capstone project in which students will conduct critical analyses of the existing business models and policies related to the biotechnology industry and healthcare system. It allows students to conduct independent studies related to biotechnology, entrepreneurship and healthcare management. Students will form groups to critically analyze selected companies or policies on healthcare and/or environmental sustainability so that they will be motivated by how these companies, policies, or management strategies are running and their significance in contributing to society. Students will apply knowledge and techniques learned from courses of the relevant concentration areas and conduct a deeper study into specific topics of their interests in biotechnology, entrepreneurship and/or healthcare management. Students and instructors will conduct progress meetings on a regular basis. Students are expected to give oral presentations and submit their reports at the end of the course.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Course Schedule**

* *Phase 1: Preparation and Topic Selection (Weeks 1-3)**

* *Activities:**

* Idea generation with outside guests(s) (1-2 hours).
* Overview of course objectives and expectations.
* Group formation and role assignment.
* Selection and approval of topics for analysis.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours):**

* Confirm group roles and responsibilities.
* Alignment of topics with course goals.
* Guidance on research sources.

* *Phase 2: Research and Analysis (Weeks 4-7)**

* *Activities:**

* Conduct research on selected topics/areas.
* Perform critical analysis using frameworks.
* Develop initial insights and findings.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours):**

* Review research progress and identify challenges.
* Assess the depth of analysis and provide feedback.
* Discuss insights and their implications for recommendations.

* *Phase 3: Recommendations Development (Weeks 8-11)**

* *Activities:**

* Formulate actionable recommendations based on analysis.
* Discuss feasibility and alignment with business objectives.
* Prepare presentation materials summarizing findings.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours) :**

* Review draft recommendations for improvement.
* Discuss implementation strategies.
* Provide feedback on presentation content and clarity.

* *Phase 4: Presentation and Reflection (Weeks 12-14)**

* *Activities:**

* Deliver final presentations to peers and instructors.
* Reflect on the overall project experience.
* Submit individual reflection reports on learning outcomes.

* *Consultation by Instructors (2 hours) :**

* Provide feedback on presentation performance
* Discuss strengths and areas for improvement.
* Reflect on teamwork dynamics and project outcomes.

courses.subject: BEHM
courses.title: Capstone Project II
courses.description: This course is part II of the capstone project which is a continuation of the analytical work undertaken by students in the BEHM4001 Capstone Project I, focusing on utilizing research findings to enhance business models and policies within the biotechnology and healthcare sectors. After critically evaluating the companies or policies investigated in Capstone Project I, students should ideate and design a prototype based on the recommendations they developed for optimizing these business practices, improving operational efficiency, and fostering sustainable development. Students are encouraged to test and improve their prototypes, establish their start-ups or NGOs wherever practicable to foster entrepreneurial skills, and provide them with practical experience in developing and implementing strategies, through applying their knowledge and skills acquired from the previous coursework and employing innovative thinking to address real-world challenges. Guidance will be provided by the instructor and regular consultations will ensure the alignment of project objectives. By the end of this course, students will present their proposals through comprehensive oral presentations and provide detailed portfolios, demonstrating their ability to apply theoretical concepts to practical scenarios and contribute meaningfully to biotechnology or healthcare management.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

* Make recommendations, ideation and produce prototypes: suggest practical recommendations to enhance practices and increase efficiency, actualize ideation through establishing and testing prototypes.
* Apply knowledge: through applying knowledge learned from previous courses to solve real-world challenges in biotechnology and healthcare.
* Effectively collaborate: work well in teams, demonstrating good communication and collaboration skills.
* Think creatively: use innovative thinking to propose solutions that support sustainability and benefit society.
* Present ideas clearly: share findings through professional oral presentations and portfolios.
* Reflect on experience: reflect on personal contributions and the learning process to support continuous improvement.
* Establish new business: gain practical experience in developing and implementing business strategies.
courses.course_syllabus:
There is no lecture in this course. Students are expected to meet with instructors regularly throughout the term.

* *Course Schedule**

* *Phase 1: Project Planning and Research Application (Weeks 1-4)**

* *Activities:**

Review findings from Capstone Project I.

Define overall objectives and scope for Capstone II.

Outline research methodologies and data collection strategies.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours):**

Confirm project objectives and group roles.

Discuss the alignment of chosen topics with research goals.

Provide guidance on relevant data sources and research techniques.

* *Phase 2: Analysis and Recommendations Development (Weeks 5-8)**

* *Activities:**

Identify key issues and opportunities based on the analysis.

Formulate actionable recommendations for improvement.

Employ innovative thinking to address real-world challenges.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours):**

Review research findings and critical analysis.

Discuss the feasibility and impact of proposed recommendations.

Provide feedback on the rationale behind recommendations.

* *Phase 3: Implementation Planning (Weeks 9-12)**

* *Activities:**

Develop detailed implementation plans for recommendations.

Identify potential challenges and strategies to overcome them.

Discuss stakeholder engagement and communication plans.

* *Consultation by Instructors (3 hours):**

Review implementation strategies and timelines.

Discuss risk management and mitigation approaches.

Provide insights on best practices for stakeholder communication.

* *Phase 4: Presentation and Reflection (Weeks 13-16)**

* *Activities:**

Prepare and deliver final presentations summarizing findings, recommendations, and implementation plans.

Reflect on the project experience and group dynamics.

Submit individual reflection reports on learning outcomes.

* *Consultation by Instructors (2 hours):**

Provide feedback on presentation effectiveness and clarity.

Discuss overall project performance and lessons learned.

Reflect on teamwork, collaboration, and personal growth throughout the project.

Compile detailed progress reports summarizing the analysis and recommendations.
